title.narrative: Advancing Gender Equality through Economic and Social Empowerment, and Protection Services targeting Women and Girls

description.narrative: The project aims to benefit 500 households from vulnerable communities in Amman, Aqaba and Zarqa. The direct beneficiaries are estimated to be 65% females 35% males. The total estimated number of beneficiaries from all households engaged with this programs activities (livelihood, training, women empowerment and better parenting, case management, child centre activities, youth activities and psychosocial support) is estimated to be 2400.

recipient-country.narrative: Using a holistic approach to development through case management, our targets are family units instead of individuals. As such, the project will benefit both female and male, recognizing the gender variances in the family social structure and tailoring specific services to empower each gender and age group accordingly. 500 adult females and males will benefit from access to livelihood component with a 60% female and 40% male distribution. These participants and other adults of both genders in the family will also benefit from knowledge and information, and Better Parenting components. Children, adolescents and youth of both genders will benefit from improved family environment promoting education opportunities, technical, vocational, and life skills training, and recreational and leadership activities. All age segments in the family will also benefit from increased resilience of all family members.

sector.narrative: The project aims to address the interlinked nature of livelihood and protection threats by empowering women economically to become part of the workforce, and by addressing cases of GBV and domestic violence. JRF’s innovative approach focuses on achieving a lasting positive trickle-down effect on families and communities at large; by addressing each family as a functional healthy family unit – merging both livelihood and family protection tracks. Using JRF’s holistic approach, the project aspires to help vulnerable families improve resilience and achieve self-reliance through: • Access to livelihoods: Improve access to practical skills and gainful employment; this is managed through JRF’s Community Empowerment Program (CEP), offering two tracks: generation/expansion of micro and small enterprises, and job placement in private sector organizations. • Child safety and family protection: Identify at-risk children, including those engaged in child labor and victims of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), such as early marriage, and increase access to preventative and protective case management interventions. The project also aims to build and reinforce a healthy and functional family unit and home environment to ensure child safety through the provision of effective women empowerment and parenting sessions. This will be managed through local family protection units with a family advisor assigned to oversee progress within each family.

description.narrative: A market assessment was conducted to identify and assess market opportunities and gaps through an in-depth market assessment of the value-chain within the targeted areas. A triangulation assessment technique was implemented adopting both quantitative and qualitative assessment methodologies, through structured questionnaires, Focus Group Discussions, and individual interviews. Furthermore, the assessment will include Key Informant Interviews with relevant key stakeholders and entities, to ensure an in-depth understanding and comprehensive mapping exercise.

title.narrative: Market Assessment Report Report was released internally.

description.narrative: JRF training and consultancy division have developed and tailored specific assessment tools in order to achieve the outcomes below:  Identifying the micro-business understating and most common trends in the areas.  Understanding the labor market and work-force in the areas.  Investigate areas of intervention and local community understanding of child protection and domestic violence  Understanding the soft-skills required in individuals enrolling in Micro-business stream or work force in order to develop and tailor the training content accordingly. the assessment revolved around seeking answers for the below mentioned questions: Community mapping: 1. What is the level of unemployment among the randomly selected assessment sample, and those looking for work? 2. What are the individual skills of the target population? 3. What is the extent of reliance on casual (temporary) versus formal work within the households in the target areas? 4. What are the protection related needs in the target areas? 5. What are the current levels of access to and needs for access to protection information and services, in the target community? And What are the main protection concerns in the community, and how are households or individuals currently coping with these shocks? Micro - business: 1. What are the current predominant enterprises of Syrian refugees and Jordanians living in the target areas? • What are the main skills requirements? • What are the potential areas of business (business ideas) for the target population? • What skills are required to run the enterprises successfully? Work – Force: 1. What are the market sectors that have the biggest demand of job opportunities (sectors and sub-sectors)? 2. What are the barriers and incentives for the available job opportunities disaggregated by sub-sectors? 3. What are the accessible locations where the targeted population accept and are willing to travel to for work (economic catchment zones)? Do they have the propensity to broader economic mobility?

Khawla Bint AlAzwar CBO in Zarqa based on specific criteria developed by JRF M&E team was selected. To ensure successful implementation of activities, JRF built the capacities of the CBO through a 5 - day Institutional Strengthening Training Program. its main purpose is elevating the capacities of the CBOs through exposing them to financial, organizational, managerial, procurement, and grants management training. JRF will support the partner CBO in Zarqa to function as a Family and Child Protection Center.

title.narrative: CBO capacity building and SOP training

description.narrative: 5 members of the CBO staff received the capacity building training.the training aim to elevate the capacities of the CBOs through exposing them to financial, organizational, managerial, procurement, and grants management training.SOP training; to ensure the quality of provided services to beneficiaries a 3 days training on following the standard procedures at JRF was given to the 3 teams in the 3 targeted governorates. Followed by a technical training on case management for the project 3 case managers, where they received 12 days of technical training.
The capacity building program consist of two parts; i. Foundation Value Driven Training. ii. Micro and Small Enterprises Track. iii. Job Placement Training.

title.narrative: 8 groups with total of 200 beneficiaries received the Foundation Value Driven Training, and 4 groups with total of 100 beneficiaries received the advanced Micro and Small Enterprises Track training.

comment.narrative: 200 beneficiaries received and completed the value driven training. out of which 100 beneficiaries, received the advanced Micro and Small Enterprises Track training.

description.narrative: The community based meetings/information sessions is a key tool in raising awareness and buy-in of the project objectives, approach, target groups, eligibility and selection criteria, as well as to encourage community members to apply

title.narrative: 20 info sessions were conducted in the 3 targeted areas, around 1300+ attendees.

description.narrative: 20 info sessions instead of 8 were conducted in the 3 targeted areas; to expand the in-depth outreach to the most vulnerable households to participate in the project. with average of 75 attendees per session instead of 150. The session is followed by one-to-one interview, 250 household were selected based on criteria developed by JRF through several processes including socio-economic profiling questionnaires, interviews, and the tailored selection criteria.
